description.narrative: Disposing of hazardous chemicals (DDT) and controlling the spread of disease by mosquitoes
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level
Number of additional males benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Number of additional females benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Total number of additional people benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Number of men above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
Number of women above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
Total number of people above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
Disposing of hazardous chemicals (DDT) and controlling the spread of disease by mosquitoes
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

• Regulatory and enforcement capacity in place • Obsolete pesticides disposed of • PCBs phased out and disposed of • Reduced risk of exposure to POPs of project-affected people • Knowledge management packages developed, and • Viability/cost-effectiveness of alternatives to POPs, particularly in Theme-1, is demonstrated in a number of settings

comment.narrative:
Stockholm Convention is not fully incorporated into national legislation. The POPs National Implementation identifies following priorities:
• Disposal of obsolete POPs chemicals and decontamination of POPs-infested areas • Development of alternative strategies for malaria vector management with reduced—or no—reliance on DDT
Completion of Terminal Evaluation Completion of Responsible Care programme COmpletion of IVM volunteer work. Disposal of Ethylene Oxide Cylinders

The Terminal EValuation was completed in June 2015 The responsible care programme was completed following the national awareness campaign in September 2015 The IVM volunteer work was completed in March, with the final report of the IVM coordinator assistant Co-financing has been identified for the disposal of ethylene oxide cylinders.
Disposal of Ethylene Oxide Cylinders completed

description.narrative: Objective To expand and ensure effective management of the protected area network to safeguard threatened biodiversity
1 Coverage ha of the terrestrial formal protected area network of mainland Mauritius and the islets

comment.narrative:
State protected areas
8027ha
Private protected areas
0ha

State protected areas
11700ha
Private protected areas
3220ha

The status quo in terms of protected areas has been maintained
State Protected areas 8328 ha
Private protected areas 0 ha
For Bassin Blanc acquisition under appeal in valuation tribunal is still not finalized
The management plans for the Bras dEau National Park and Black River Gorges National Park have been submitted during this reporting periodBoth document proposes the creation of buffer zones these will be delineated in the mapping under the Protected Area Network Expansion Strategy Yet the whole process of declaring the land around the parks must be initiated by the Ministry of Housing and Lands which is the local authority to define the land uses
Regarding Mountain and River Reserves which covers approximately 6500 ha of privately managed land their status as protected areas is still unclear The Protected Area Network Expansion Strategy expected for September 2015 will provide the underpinnings for adding these reserves and other potential reserves such as the corridor of 4000 metres linking Le Morne to the Black River Gorges National Park to the protected area networks
Concerning the Native Terrestrial Biodiversity and National Parks Bill which makes provision for proclamation of of private reserves is expected to be presented to the parliament in October 2015

description.narrative:
2 Total operational budget including HR and capital budget allocation US for protected area management
Note added to clarify that this indicator refers to the annual budget

comment.narrative: US23m
More than US41m

Target can be considered as being achieved The total budget for PAs as Government budget allocation 2014 is estimated to be 62 m for the Forestry services and 24 m include funds from PAN project approximately 800000 for the National Parks and Conservation services Additional funds of US 025 m from National Parks and conservation funds has been used for Protected Areas Other financing mechanism are also now in place such a Maurice Ile Durable MID fund to the tune of US 0 4 m for Protected Areas management Moreover funds from private companies Corporate Social Responsibility CSR have also been allocated as follows HSBC US 25000 IBL US 2500 Lions clubs US 8500 Total budget amounts to US 925 m

description.narrative: 3 Financial sustainability score for national systems of protected areas

comment.narrative: Baseline application of the of the Financial Sustainability Scorecard 2009 yielded a general score of 17

Application of the of the Financial Sustainability Scorecard at project end is expected to yield a general score 3040
Target adjusted after conclusion of inception report

Target achieved Financial Scorecard has not been reworked for this reporting period Initiatives undertaken in 2013 and 2014 to improve the financial score of the PAs are still ongoing Private companies are still directly contributing to PAs management in terms of ecosystem restoration and IAS removal activities in the PAs The lions club a service group is channeling CSR funds from private companies for IAS clearing and forest restoration activities The Maurice Ile Durable has continued to fund PA management and Ecosystem restoration in newly identified areas There will soon be another source of funds from the European Union The Indian Ocean Commission IOC have called for proposal for local biodiversity project to the tune of US 36 000 to US 90 000 per projectDeadline for submission of Project is August 2015

description.narrative: 4 Capacity development indicator score for protected area system

comment.narrative:
Systemic 50
Institutional 56
Individual 62

Systemic 78
Institutional 60
Individual 75
Target adjusted after conclusion of inception report

The Scorecard has not been applied again Hence it is not possible to inform the indicator The Capacity development indicator will be calculated after the training programme has been finalized The score generated will serve as a baseline The Capacity Development indicator will be generated a second time after training completed and the outcome will be measure against the baseline
Concerning the training need analysis the exercise is nearly completed and data analysis should start soon
Otherwise an ecological restoration workshop to share good ecosystem restoration practice through the development of a practitioners guidemanual is planned for SeptemberOctober 2015
Regarding actual training carried out during this reporting period there has been two training sessions in December 2014 on the use of GPS Staff from the Forestry services NPCS and Ministry of Housing and Lands attended the training

description.narrative:
9 Reach of the communications and awareness programme as follows

9b Percentage of those participating in experiential learning programmes instigated by the PAN who show positive changes in behavior
NOTE ON LOGFRAME REVISION 2014
Indicator 9 has been revised as a result of the MTR It was not being properly informed in previous reporting periods anyway
It was previously formulated as follows
Reach estimated number of people of the communications and awareness programme
The MTR recommended this changed The response was
Reach indicator does not tell us anything about the takeup of messages This indicator will be improved It will be based upon surveys of target audiences and these groups will be surveyed for changes in their knowledge attitudes and practices regarding general issues of biodiversity conservation in Mauritius and specific project protected area network objectives
Training indicators have been revised to be outcomeoriented

comment.narrative:
In order to adequately assess the target now as a of those reached out by the project tailored surveys will need to be applied

Outreach programmes number of people attending tbd
Experiential learning programmes number of people attending tbd

9a At least 80 of those participating in experiential learning programmes show enhanced knowledge and attitude
9b At least 50 of those participating in experiential learning programmes show positive changes in behavior
NOTE ON LOGFRAME REVISION 2014
Target for indicator 9 It was previously formulated as follows
Broadbased communications estimated number of audience receiving different media message approx 100000
Outreach programmes number of people attending approx 500
Experiential learning programmes number of people attending approx 500
Lobbying of key decisionmakers number of people and institutions 10 of 4

Further progress have been made towards the target Since the facebook page has been created in July 2014 the number of likes has add up to 960 The awareness campaign is still being implemented with future experiential events coming A National art competition on the theme of world biodiversity was launched on the 8th May 2015 and all entries had to be submitted on the 18th May 2015 The PMU is going to do a thorough analysis of the exercise and its output to create a baselineResults from future competition will be compared to the baseline to find out whether there has been changes
In addition a national survey will be undertaken at the close of the awareness programme to look at changes in knowledge and behaviour

There has been tangible progress towards this targetThe review of the Bras dEau National Park Management plan has been fully reviewed and will soon go for public consultation process Review of the Bras DEau operational plan has been completed in June 2015 and comments have been communicated to the International Team of Consultants for amendments
Regarding the Black River Gorges National Park9BRGNP Management plan a first draft was submitted on the 16th February 2015 An amended version together with the annual operation plan AOP was submitted in June 2015 after comments were communicated The PMU is actually driving the review of the BRGNP AOP
Concerning the strategic planning there has been continuous consultation with FS and NPCS during the different EcoAfrica missions The submission of the strategic planning should follow the PANES

description.narrative: Building the capacity of stakeholders to manage freshwater resources in an integrated manner

title.narrative: UNDP GEF AIO SIDS IWRM project document

description.narrative: Building the capacity of stakeholders to manage freshwater resources in an integrated manner
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

National partners have knowledge of IWRM concepts and their roles in implementing IWRM and participate in IWRM related networks National partners are incorporating IWRM concepts and tools into their work at various levels Successful project demonstrations are replicated through other means 6 AIO SIDS have established interministerial committees managing IWRM processes 6 AIO SIDS employing monitoring framework for freshwater resources and this information informs water management

comment.narrative: Limited or no application of IWRM principles or tools and processes at various levels within SIDS Limited awareness of various stakeholdersÃ¢ roles in IWRM Little or no exchange of experience regarding IWRM and best practices amongst SIDS 2 AIO SIDS countries have national cross-sectoral IWRM committees at different levels of deveopment Limited or in some cases no freshwater resource monitoring systems in place in the 6 AIO SIDS

IWRM demonstration projects ongoing in all six countries with functional IWRM coordination committees at Basin level.
Cape Verde: Technical design completed and recommendations available Selection of household connection completed and 500 households mapped for connection to main sewer-line. Halophite plants planted to mitigate seashore erosion and salinization Targeted awareness campaigns held. Participatory IWRM workshop held.
Comoros: Water resource assessment initiated and draft reports available. Socioeconomic assessment and participatory mapping and zoning initiated and draft reports available. A watershed management plan completed . Consultation on solid waste management ongoing, scenarios for solid waste management discussed. Establishment of a tripartite partnership with the University of Comoros, the Directorate of Water and Energy and Directorate of Environment and Forest w In March and April 2015, Training for small scale farmers held to promote soil erosion control practices. Workshops held on the development of watershed management plans for Mutsamundu river basin, and implementation approach agreed on
An integrated water supply plan was completed and technical design prepared and approved. 100% (about 2000) population of the Island will have have portable water supply. Bidding was completed and contractor hired. Works was commissioned by the Minister in May 2015 Water planning Committee for the Island was established, and actively involved in planning. The committee involves the Island Authorities, technical departments such as agriculture and fisheries as well as education and community representatives.
Mauritius: As regards Output 1.4.1: Water Resources Assessment conducted to determine and monitor the safe yield and water quality of the aquifer - a consultant was appointed and specifications prepared for the drilling of 4-5 boreholes and installation of piezometers. Output 1.4.2: Improved water quality protection of the gr

IWRM demonstration projects are ongoing in all six countries with functional IWRM coordination committees at Basin level. Through the multi-stakeholder plat forms and participatory approach, the project has created platform for addressing water challenges and awareness raising, effectively raising awareness at national level on benefits of IWRM adoption. Following the demonstration project intervention, number of gaps have been identified and policy recommendations made.
Cape Verde: Technical design completed and recommendations available Selection of household connection has been completed and 580 household mapped for connection to main sewer-line. This is expected to increase volume of wastewater by 40% A total of 1750 halophite plants were planted to mitigate seashore erosion and salinization Seven major targeted awareness campaigns have been held reaching out to over 750 people. This include two events during a national fair on Environment in 2014 and 2015 in which over 250 persons visited the project promotional stand. In February 2014, a 3-days participatory IWRM workshop was held, raising awareness among key national level senior officials (a total of 28 participants representing different departments in the water sector). From September to November 2014, awareness raising events on theme "water is life" were held in Tarraffal involving primary and secondary schools students and teachers. Over 200 students were involved and sensitized.
Comoros: Water resource assessment initiated and draft reports available. Socioeconomic assessment and participatory mapping and zoning initiated and draft reports available. A watershed management plan is expected to be completed by September 2015. Consultation on solid waste management is ongoing, scenarios for solid waste management have discussed. A monthly solid waste cleaning day has been agreed on. Additionally, through project mobilization, several solid waste collection campaigns were held involving the gen

6 SIDS countries develop IWRM plans meeting MDG target 7a
Subsets of the AIO SIDS show demonstrable progress in improving water use efficiency and access to safe drinking water andor basin sanitation thereby making progress on MDG targets 7b or 7c respectively P
Specific improvements in water resources management at 6 national demonstration sites
National interministerial committees support IWRM processes in 6 SIDS by close of project
Mechanisms in place to monitor freshwater resources in 6 SIDS by close of project

National partners have knowledge of IWRM concepts and their roles in implementing IWRM and participate in IWRM related networks
National partners are incorporating IWRM concepts and tools into their work at various levels
Successful project demonstrations are replicated through other means
6 AIO SIDS have established interministerial committees managing IWRM processes
6 AIO SIDS employing monitoring framework for freshwater resources and this information informs water management

IWRM demonstration projects are ongoing in all six countries with functional IWRM coordination committees at Basin level Through the multistakeholder plat forms and participatory approach the project has created platform for addressing water challenges and awareness raising effectively raising awareness at national level on benefits of IWRM adoption Following the demonstration project intervention number of gaps have been identified and policy recommendations made

description.narrative:
Improved water source protection through IWRM Planning and management in Mutsamudu on the island of Anjouan
Outputs
121 Water resource assessment and monitoring systems established
122 Water quality improved through solid waste management and water source protection
123 Reservoir protected from the effects of smallscale farming practices
124 Watershed management plan for Mutsamudu developed
125 Awareness raised on IWRM and catchment management and its contribution to MDGs and gender empowerment

Water resources assessed at identified monitoring points Water resource monitoring operational
Solid waste collection system established and operational
Volumeweight solid waste collected
Volumearea of monitoring point covered in solid waste
Catchment management committee established
Watershed management plan
of training and awareness raising campaigns with gender disaggregated data on water source protection from solid waste and agricultural practice

comment.narrative:
No water quality or quantity monitoring data collected
No collection system amount of solid waste in River Mutsamudu not monitored
No committee exists
No plan exists no data collection or analysis exists to provide basis for management plan
No community engagement on solid waste pollution little awareness observed

Regular water resources monitoring programme established
of households increased serviced by solid waste collection system
30 reduction in solid waste observed at the monitoring point upstream of water supply intake
Committee established with clear TORs and operational
Consultation with landowners and catchment sh completed watershed surveys conducted watershed zone map produced management plan endorsed by stakeholders
Clean up campaigns attended by communities all farmers in the area around reservoirs trained in best farming practice to reduce pollution on reservoir

Water resource assessment initiated and draft reports available Socioeconomic assessment and participatory mapping and zoning initiated and draft reports available A watershed management plan is expected to be completed by September 2015
Consultation on solid waste management is ongoing scenarios for solid waste management have discussed A monthly solid waste cleaning day has been agreed on Additionally through project mobilization several solid waste collection campaigns were held involving the general public schools and military Over 50 of the population of Anjuaon has been sensitized through various channels including outreach activities workshops and media local radio and press
in April 2015 a tripartite partnership with the University of Comoros the Directorate of Water and Energy and Directorate of Environment and Forest was established for water quality monitoring Under the partnership the laboratory of the University of Comoros has been upgraded for water quality monitoring On the otherhand the University is providing ongoing technical support in monitoring and training
In March and April 2015 two training for small scales farmers was held to promote soil erosion control practices Training included onsite demonstration of good practices in which 10 small scale farmers were involved
Two workshops were held on the development of watershed management plans for Mutsamundu river basin and implementation approach agreed on

description.narrative:
Integrated River basin management plan for the Rio Provaz Basin developed to enable equitable water resources allocation and protection contributing to sustainable economic development public health and environmental protection
Outputs
151 Quality and quantity of water Resources in the Rio Provaz basin assessed
152 Institutional capacity crosssectoral coordination strengthened and decentralized municipal water management fostered through the development and implementation of Basin Water Resources Allocation and Protection Strategy
153 Water pollution reduced through improved wastewater treatment systems piloting ECOSAN wastewater management solid waste collection and disposal and residential sanitation at the poor communities
154 Awareness raised of IWRM at the basin level to strengthen community participation in IWRM and to ensure sustainability

Area surveyed and reported
Water resources level flow and quality data GW resources potential established
Basin water management committee Basin Water Resources Allocation and Protection Strategy
of households using Ecosan

comment.narrative:
No formal inventories of land or water resources or use exists
No regular data collection or quality assurance
No stakeholder consultations on water resources management to date no catchment management committee no water resources management strategies at basin level or national level
No Ecosan technology currently used

100 of catchments area surveyed
Robust quantity and quality data sets collected all major risk type assessed for GW extraction
Stakeholders identified Gender integrated catchment management committees established and operational water resources management strategy developed in a participatory manner and endorsed by the basin stakeholders the process at the demo basin informs the national level IWRM process
100 of constructed Ecosan units still in use at the end of the project of units TBD during the inception phase lessons learned produced aiming for further promotion

Water Resource Assessment and mapping of Rio Provaz Basin was undertaken 100 of the basin has been surveyed and mapped and draft reported submitted Water resource status has been simulated from limited data available
Basin coordination committee established at list 5 meeting held committee members are trained on 7 relevant aspects
On solid waste a large amount of solid waste has been cleared and this continues with an estimated solid waste collection at 20 m3 per month Several awareness campaigns have been carried out to raise awareness on river basin protection at least 50 of the population has been reached
A specialized firm to support on Ecosanitation promotion training and construction has been recruited Work is scheduled to start thereafter

backstopping

comment.narrative: GHG in the electricity generation sector scheduled to increase from 203 million tonsyear 2008 figures to almost 33 million tonsyear by the year 2020

11662 2 MWh of electricity generated as a result of the 3 MW capacity brought online by project completion
Direct reduction of 13295 tons of CO2 over the 4year FSP project life cycle and 98400 over the full lifetime of the plants
Estimated cumulative indirect GHG emission reduction of at least 350000 tons of CO2eq by 2025 on the basis of a conservative policy scenario and a GEF causality factor of 80

17 MW of PV have been installed as a result of an additional private promoters 15 MW installation coming into operation and around 2 MW of SmallScale Distributed Generation SSDG Therefore direct emission reductions are estimated to be 9928 ktonnes of CO2

title.narrative: Climate Change Adaptation in Coastal Zones

description.narrative: Climate Change adaptation programme targeting the vulnerable coastal zones of the Republic of Mauritius

title.narrative: Mid Term Evaluation of the Climate Change Adaptation in the Coastal Zone of Mauritius project

description.narrative: Increasing resilience of communities and livelihoods in vulnerable coastal areas of Mauritius in response to climate change
independent political entity

No. of physical assets strengthened or constructed to withstand conditions resulting from climate variability and change.
Relevant threat and hazard information generated and disseminated to stakeholders on a timely basis.
No. of staff trained to respond to, and mitigate impacts of, climate-related events.
Policies introduced or adjusted to address climate change risks.

comment.narrative:
Outcome 1. - Concept Architectural Design of Refuge Centre validated at National Workshop -Final Detailed Design Reports for Coastal Adaptation Measures at Mon Choisy including cost estimates and EIA
Outcome 2 - Installation, Implementation and Commissioning of EWS Models - Training of personnel - Submission of Training Materials, Review of Communication linkages assessment of effectiveness of EWS.
Outcome 3 - Short Course on Coastal Engineering - Training of Coastal Communities with EcoBus (2)
Outcome 4 - Launching of Request for Proposal for Consultancy Services for drafting of the National Coastal Zone Adaptation Strategy for the Republic of Mauritius.
Outcome 5 - Development of Learning/sensitisation Materials on Climate Change Adaptation (Electronic Application for Android Phones) - Development of 3D Ecosystem and Climate Change Small Scale Models -

Deliverables completed for Mon Choisy Riviere des Galets coastal areas : (i) Technical Assessment (ii) Adaptation Options Reports including CBA (iii) Feasibility Study (iv) Draft Design of Adaptation Measures incl. cost estimates. With regard to construction of Refuge Centre at Quatre Soeurs the following deliverables had been completed during the year; (i) Detailed Site Assessment, Survey Geotechnical Study of Site (ii) Architectural Concept – approved (iii) Draft Design Report (iv) Draft Tender Documents.

Outcome 1 Construction of Refuge Centre at Quatre Soeurs - 50% Completion Coastal Adaptation Works at Mon Choisy - Bid Document finalized for Coastal Adaptation Works at Mon Choisy Coastal Adaptation Works at Riviere des Galets - • Bid Document finalized and Procurement of Works initiated
Outcome 3 - Training and Capacity Building - Short Course on Cost Benefit Analysis applied to Climate Change Initiatives completed - Training Manual on Cost-Benefit Analysis for Coastal Management and Adaptation Options to Climate Change in Mauritius finalized and launched - Draft Handbook on Coastal Adaptation for Coastal Communities - 1,000 people sensitized on Climate Change Adaptation using Marine Mobile Educational Unit
Outcome 4 - Policy Mainstreaming Contract for Consultancy Services for Preparation of a National Coastal Zone Adaptation Strategy for the Republic of Mauritius awarded
Outcome 5 - Knowledge Dissemination and Management - A Do’s and Don’ts sheet at sea sheet with the pouch for boat operators and fishermen completed - Electronic game application on climate change targeted for children completed and uploaded on the App Store

title.narrative: Energy Efficiency in buildings and industry

description.narrative: Removal of barriers to Energy Efficiency and Energy conservation in buildings and industry

title.narrative: Energy Efficiency in buildings and industry

description.narrative: Removal of barriers to Energy Efficiency and Energy conservation in buildings and industry
independent political entity

• EAMS Regulations • Report on sustainability planning of EEMO • Administrative tools and procedures developed for EEMO • Regulations of designated consumers for mandatory energy audits • Report on adequacy of existing regulations

comment.narrative: Lack of regulations and codes for energy savings in buildings and industries, and need for operationalization of the EEMO, Lack of energy saving services and technology in the building and industrial sectors Lack of trained energy auditors on the market Lack of a framework for energy savings in Industries,
EAMs consultant appointed Energy Audit Certification completed Energy Efficiency Information Management system launched Building Energy Efficiency Compliance training completed

Under Lot 1, Econoler has carried out a one-day inception workshop on 07 July 2015. It was a platform for the Consultants to introduce the participants to the project and their firm. They provided their appreciation regarding the SIDS-Dock project’s framework and indicators and discussed on the methodology for the study. The Consultants further elaborated on the approach they would adopt concerning the customization of the MBEAT/Excel software. The Consultants also explained on their approach to conducting Energy Audits and to ensuring compatibility of the Energy Audit Management Scheme (EAMS) adopted by EEMO with the outcomes of the study. The participants also had the opportunity to provide their comments and suggestions regarding the various aspects of the inception report. Under Lot 2, Econoler has already carried out 3 missions to Mauritius. During the first mission, a one-day inception workshop was held on 16 June 2015. It was a platform for the Consultants to introduce the participants to the project and their firm. They provided their appreciation regarding the SIDS-Dock project’s framework and indicators and discussed on the methodology for the study. The Consultants also elaborated on the approach they would adopt concerning the review of the existing GoM architectural specifications and construction methods. The Consultants further explained on their approach to developing the MS Excel-based software tool and to developing the Energy Efficiency Building Code Compliance Scheme (EEBCCS). The participants also had the opportunity to provide their comments and suggestions regarding the various aspects of the inception report. During the second mission, a one-day consultative workshop was held on 29 July 2015. It was a platform where the Consultants introduced the participants on the Energy Efficiency Building Regulations (EEBR) and the Energy Efficiency Building Code (EEBC) project backgrounds and statuses. They presented the elements of the EEBR and EEB

Completion of energy audits completion of technical support to EEMO Terminal Evaluation Completion of Energy Efficiency Information Management System Certification of Energy Auditors and Building Compliance Assessors

description.narrative: The ‘Social Inclusion and Empowerment’ project is designed to support the Government of Mauritius and Non-State Actors in exploring more effective ways of addressing poverty and the exclusion of vulnerable groups.
Building the capacity of non-state actors and vulnerable in policy formulation and implementation
populated place
independent political entity
first-order administrative division
Other General Services - support to civil society

Increased inclusion of the poor in ministerial (MSIEE) pro-poor programmes.
Quality of M E Framework of the NEF projects by NEF staff.
The NSA’s capacity to design and utilise ME tools at project level.
The presence of a Gender Specific Professional.
The number of local federations of social actors; the number of self-managed federations of social actors. The number of federations that are capable of identifying community development or pro-poor priorities.

comment.narrative:
Absence of a coordinated participatory community development approach to ensure optimal coverage for the poor in Mauritius/Rodrigues.
The current ministerial (MSIEE) database of beneficiaries amongst the poor used for the provision of services is unreliable: rough estimates suggest that both leakage and under-coverage are significant (about 35%).
There is an absence of any formal M E framework for projects, formulated and implemented by the National Empowerment Foundation (NEF). The NEF does not have the ability to translate results into information requirements on an ongoing basis.
The specific needsof excluded groups, especially women are not yet adequately addressed through Community Development.
Mauritius/Rodrigues does not have locally and participatory integrated community development.

Output 1: Conduct a training on Results-based planning Management; Carry out Programs' operation audit (Assess the gaps, inconsistencies in the NEF programs' core documents; Documentation of best practices emerging out of the NEF interventions; Support the Marshall Plan and Poverty observatory Integration of Monitoring Evaluation modules in projects at NEF M E manual
Output 2: Finalize 3 draft gender policies Support the Ministry of Gender - Social Action Committees
Output 3: Increase number of projects managed by platform Reinforced capacities of e xecutive members of platforms (Board) Development of operational structure and assistance to other satellites in the Republic of Mauritius. Formulating Social Entrepreneurship potential at grassroots Continue to build up capacity of volunteers Engage in future expansion of platform model to other areas of the island, with possible partnership with MACOSS, in view of a generalized model of coordinated intervention in pockets of poverty (adding Parrainage as private sector support to community development)

Output1: In line with paragraphs 173-179 of the March 2015 government Budget Speech 2015-2016, and the cabinet decision on 3rd April 2015, regarding the Marshall plan against poverty, the government of Mauritius has adopted to use the Social Register Mauritius (SRM) for the NEF School Materials scheme and other social protection programmes .From June-December 2015, in partnership with the Ministry of Social Security (MSS), Ministry of Finance and Economic Development (MoFED), the Nation Empowerment Foundation (NEF) and with the assistance of Statistics Mauritius(SM) and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), the Ministry of Social Integration and Economic Empowerment (MSIE) has launched a national campaign to register all vulnerable families in SRM. NEF project staff were deployed to the field to collect information on printed SRM questionnaires, which were then entered into the Social Register Mauritius system by MSS Officers. The eligibility of the applicants concerning the income status was verified using by PMT, which is built-in, the SRM system. Findings from the SRM registration exercise are expected to guide the identification and prioritization of the genuine and poorest communities across the Island. The purpose of SRM is not only to assist government in identifying the beneficiaries of social programs and deciding the level of assistance for each beneficiary. But also, it is a tool that helps measuring the proportion of vulnerable families which have been sustainably pulled above the Relative Poverty line over time. However, overall, the awareness of the SRM and available schemes is still not optimal among the poor and thus additional outreach and information campaign are advisable and should be ongoing until all of the potential beneficiaries are registered.Moreover, there is need to keep strengthening the results-based monitoring and evaluation system at MSIEE/NEF level to allow technical staff to be capable of carrying out regular process

Output 1: Support to implementation of Marshall Plan -NEF restructuring/Impact assessment/ Design Social Contract/Management Information System
Out put 2 : Gender -Setting up of a Gender Caucus
Output 3: Setting up a Council of Social Work Setting up a family doctor project in Rodrigues•
Professionalize Social sector To train 400 NGO volunteers on the Basic Course in Social Work. To ensure RPL certification of 200 NGO representatives.

Output 1: Support to implementation of Marshall Plan The Impact assessment and Design Social Contract have been successfully completed. As for the NEF restructuring, the probably to get this study completed is very likely by end of December 2016. Given that the NEF restructuring is crucial to determine the Management Information System, hence it did not materialize this year.
Out put 2 : Gender The Setting up of a Gender Caucus was completed, the motion for implementation was approved 6th December 2016
Output 3: Setting up a Council of Social Work The Setting up a family doctor project in Rodrigues was completed in August 2016 and the Rodrigues Regional Assembly is using this study to earmark funds for implementation in Budget 2017/2018
Professionalize Social sector The training of 400 NGO volunteers on the Basic Course in Social Work. was done and they were awarded certificates on the International Volunteer day 2015. As RPL certification of 200 NGO representatives, this was not completed however UNDP supported in setting up a National Council of Social Work to regulate the sector

title.narrative: Planning and Resource Management for Inclusive Growth

description.narrative: Improving capacity of Government agencies in strategic planning, performance-based budgeting and effective service delivery, with a focus on social expenditure.
Building capacities in planning and management of public expenditure to improve effectiveness of public resources with a focus on social protection
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - policy, planning and administration

Effective strategic planning framework in place with allocation of resources linked to long-term and mid-term priorities; PBB Strategic Plans implemented by Ministries, Departments, RRA, other Local Government and all Statutory Bodies
New PFM framework in place; improved capacities and results in performance budgeting , monitoring and control of public expenditure as measured by PEFA assessments; independent budget analysis by CSOs
Learning management system in place; number of staff who have completed web-based courses
Number of social schemes using SRM and PMT; PMT based on latest HBS and Census data

comment.narrative:
Lack of a long-term national plan to support PBB formulation; weak integration of PBB Strategic Plans in budget cycle; PBB Strategic Plans partially prepared by RRA and Statutory bodies; PBB Strategic Plans not prepared by Local Government
Accountability and transparency gaps in existing PFM legislation; lack of e-budgeting and on-line monitoring system; lack of integrated annual reporting; limited budget education in CSOs
Lack of a web-based learning management system; focus on traditional forms of learning; remaining capacity gaps in PFM and public sector management
SRM and PMT applied to crèches and social housing schemes; PMT based on 2005/06 HBS

- Foresight capacities for an innovative Civil Service strengthened - Draft Marshall Plan against Poverty submitted to Government of Mauritius - Budget framework simplified - PEFA assessment 2015 reviewed - One evaluation programme conducted - Launching of ELS and design of new courses - Traning of NEF officers in SRM management and registration of NEF clients in SRM completed - PMT 2 installed on SRM system

- Foresight capacities strengthened in the Civil Service through Mauritius Foresight Exchange and 4 prototypes for civil service innovation proposed - Draft Marshall Plan against Poverty submitted to Government of Mauritius - Budget framework simplified and 100% of indicators documented for the first time - PEFA assessments reviewed and preliminary lists of areas identified for post PEFA action plan - Evaluation of the Land Drainage programme conducted with results noted by cabinet and capacity of Ministry of Finance (ME Unit) in programme evaluation strengthened - 5 new ELS courses designed and integrated - ELS management procedures formulated - Registration of NEF clients in SRM completed - 70 NEF officers trained in SRM data collection techniques - Feasibility study on mobile technology to improve outreach to the poor completed - PMT 2 installed and tested on SRM system

Vision 2030 Blueprint published -Foresight capacities for the SDGs strengthened - Final Marshall Plan against Poverty submitted to Government of Mauritius - Budget performance framework improved - Guidelines for Ministries Performance Plan formulation produced - Launching of ELS and design of new course - Training of NEF officers in SRM management and registration of NEF clients in SRM completed -Poverty mapping completed using SRM data

Vision 2030 Blueprint is being reviewed -Foresight capacities for the SDGs strengthened did not take place - Final Marshall Plan against Poverty submitted and endorsed by the Government of Mauritius - Launching of ELS and design of new course done in March 2016

The project is to integrate [Country?s] obligations under the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) into its national development and sectoral planning frameworks. It is expected to produce measurable targets for biodiversity conservation.
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Updated NBSAP available and transmitted to the CBD

comment.narrative: NBSAP not aligned with Aichi targets
-Recruitment of consultants to prepare case 3 case studies - Update of NBSAP
- Recruitment in process - Update of NBSAP delayed

- A National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan for Mauritius 2015 – 2020 developed and shared with CBD including - Study on Ecosystem Valuation in the Republic of Mauritius: A replicable approach and calculation of water ecosystem services provided by forests other reservoirs and river watersheds; a study on costed options for terrestrial ecosystem-based adaptation to climate change to be submitted for inclusion into the PoWPA.and Study on Advances in Sectoral Mainstreaming in Mauritius
- A fully functional CHM website for Mauritius
- Second Drafts of three studies and NBSAP were submitted and supposed to finalize January 2017. - CHM is created and migrating to gov.mu server.

Finalize NBSAP and three studies and submit to CBD before April 2017. Validation workshop is expected in February and share NBSAP, three studies and CHM among stakeholders. After the validation workshop, comments will be reflected on those products and then published and disseminated.

description.narrative: Strengthen national decision making towards ratification of the Minamata Convention and build capacity towards implementation of future provisions.
Strengthen national decision making towards ratification of the Minamata Convention and build capacity towards implementation of future provisions.
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration

An assessment report on the existing and required policy and regulatory framework as well as institutional capacity to implement the Convention. Mercury awareness raising activities targeting decision makers and population groups at risk such as talks, brochures, pamphlets and flyers. Capacity building and training exercises on how to conduct the mercury inventory targeting at least one representative from the relevant laboratories and institution represented in the Mercury Focus Group. Mercury Inventory (Level 2) conducted and sector description by usage of Mercury developed. A National MIA Report for the ratification and implementation of the Convention

comment.narrative: The “National Inventory of Mercury Releases in Mauritius “ developed in February 2014 under SAICM does not look in details at the institutional capacity needs at national level to implement the Minamata Convention nor does the Inventory provide an analysis of the regulatory and policy framework. As outlined in the “Mauritius National Action Plan for Mercury”, currently there is not much awareness on mercury issues among risk groups, the population and governmental institutions and agencies. No training was conducted locally on how to undertake a Level 2 mercury inventory as per the UNEP toolkit . Limited national capacities capable of performing mercury monitoring in humans and the environment
Recruitment of Project Manager launched Recruitment of International Consultant launched
Recruitment of Project Manager completed Recruitment of International Consultant launched

Recruitment of International Consultant completed Inception workshop held training on use of Level 2 assessment held • Legal Gap Analysis and Sector wise inventory reports on coal power and cement production by September 2016 and locally manufactured products containing mercury and fluorescent lamps, manometers, thermometers by November 2016 • Targeted awareness raising workshop on the jewellery sector in October 2016 • Sensitization workshop on findings of reports by December 2016
